message_text: Solving problems with your teen

@fields.child_nickname
Help @fields.child_nickname learn how to solve problems. As children get older, they become more independent and sometimes push the boundaries that we create to keep them safe.
Help your child/teen learn how to solve problems. As children get older, they become more independent and sometimes push the boundaries that we create to keep them safe.
@fields.type_of_media
@fields.child_nickname
Here's a video to help you teach @fields.child_nickname problem-solving skills!
Here's a video to help you teach your child problem-solving skills!
@fields.child_nickname
Here's an audio message to help you teach @fields.child_nickname problem-solving skills!
Here's an audio message to help you teach your child problem-solving skills!
Challenges are stressful. But problem-solving can really help. There are 6 basic steps for problem solving:

1. Identify the problem
2. Think of possible solutions
3. Figure out what the results of each solution would be
4. Choose one solution 
5. Try it out!
6. Did it work? Great! If it did not work, then try another solution
Would you like to learn more about this tip?
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean.
That's okay! You can always type "Help" if you want to receive more tips about how to manage your child's behaviour.
Would you like to learn more?
We can also teach our children the same steps.

When something bad happens, we often get upset and blame our children. But what they really need is someone to help them work through their problems. 
Take a Pause! Become aware of anger and stress. Take a deep breath or count to 10 before you react. Then respond in a calmer way.
@fields.child_nickname

Try to find solutions together:
• Allow @fields.child_nickname to express how they feel and accept their feelings. 
• Try to listen to @fields.child_nickname and see things from their perspective. 
• Thank @fields.child_nickname for being open and trusting you

Try to find solutions together:
• Allow your teen to express how they feel and accept their feelings. 
• Try to listen to your teen and see things from their perspective. 
• Thank your teen for being open and trusting you
